title: SQL UI should show an error message when the schema specified as new is an existing one in View creation/modification
description: When you create a SQL view, all column names should appear in the UI in all-uppercase, as SQL names are case-insensitive.

changeHistory.comment:
Hi Brian, 

I know that you have not checked in anything related to UI changes yet but we are facing some issues in today's nightly build (6.0-20121024). So I thought just to inform you on same.

1. Below are coming in small cases on Database settings page after creating a View regardless what we are entering

a. Viewname
b. Schema
c. Columns

2. Updating existing view with New schema with anything except small letters is giving

 "VIEW-DUPSCHEMA: (err:FOER0000) Duplicate schema: schema '<new>' already exists"

For ex - 
New
DEFAULT


3. If click on cancel on update view overlay after above step then page got refreshed and created view got disappear.


Thanks
Kuldeep
I think this is related to 19297 changes.
Quick meeting with Stephen, Mary and Brian:   All lower case for View name, Schema name and Column names in both View API level and UI level.
Bug:19882 - made suggested column names all in lower case
Bug:19882 - made suggested column names all in lower case

Stephen agreed column names in all lowercase.  Changing the suggested column names to lowercase.  Thus, for indexes, e.g. Test and test, the view UI will generate column names "test" and "test-1".

Also, note that based on the fix from http://bugtrack.marklogic.com/19297, view API is now case insensitive.  So, if the user inputs a new schema name, e.g. "Main", the user will get this error message: 
VIEW-DUPSCHEMA: (err:FOER0000) Duplicate schema: schema 'main' already exists

Hi Brian, 

Yes I confirm that column names are coming in lowercase by default on View overlay . 

But we are getting

 "VIEW-DUPSCHEMA: (err:FOER0000) Duplicate schema: schema 'new' already exists"

for entering schema name in Capital and  Sentence case for ex - 

a) NEW
b) New

So issues I reported yesterday are still there.

Thanks
Kuldeep
Stephen wanted this behavior which is different from 6.0-1

I think what you are describing is correct behavior - schema names are now case-insensitive, so "NEW" and "New" are the same name. If  a schema called "NEW" already exists and you type in "New" in the text box labelled "new schema name: " then that should throw an error.

No, actually  what I am trying to convey is that we are getting this error even in creating View first time with NEW or New as schema, it is only accepting small lettercases.


Thanks
Kuldeep

Please ignore above comment .

We are getting this error in Editing View first time with NEW or New as schema, it is only accepting small lettercases. 

Thanks
Kuldeep
Hi Kuldeep, still couldn't reproduce the problem.  Would you make a clip for the steps to reproduce?  Thanks!

Here you go!

Thanks
Verified Kuldeep's report.  Investigating...

Hi Stephen, it turns out I need additional logic in checking against existing schemas in edit mode to fix this problem.  Considering we are at such a late stage of 6.0-2, I recommend we keep the original behavior from 6.0-1 that is:   the UI is always silent about schema specification in view creation or view modification - it does not complain if schema already exists nor prompt for confirmation for schema creation if it does not exist. In other words, if the user enters a new schema name that happens to be an existing one, the UI do not complaint.  If the new schema is indeed a new one, it will be created behind the scene without any UI confirmation popup for creating a new schema.   To me, prompting for new schema creation is more meaningful to users than prompting for "are you sure this is a new schema" for specifying an existing schema because this is what the user intends to use.

Let me know if this is acceptable to you; otherwise, I need to create a new bug for it.

Thanks

I don't care about a confirmation pop-up.
  If the user types something into a text box labelled "New schema", he should expect just to create a schema with that name.

  I do care (a little bit) that if the new schema name is already in use, then the user should get an error.
  If this doesnt match current behavior, please log a separate bug.
  If it's too late to fix that bug in 6.0-2, that's OK.

Brian,

When you say "prompting for new schema creation is more meaningful to users than prompting for ...."

Are you implying that if the schema exists, we should add a prompt that  asks them to create with a different name, rather than the current message that says - "Are you sure you entered a new schema name"?

And I agree with Stephen that an error message that indicates schema already exists would be good and the cursor should go back to the "New Schema" text field.

If this is not trivial or is risky, we can move this defect.
Bug:19916 - check and warn existing schema

Per Stephen request,

Instead of silently ignoring the duplicate schema name, the UI now responses with popup message and yellow triangle with mouse-over tooltip next to the schema input field.

Steps to produce these warnings:
1) create a view with a schema name, e.g. "M1" in upper case.  The VIew UI tool will create the new view with schema name in lower case "m1".
2) edit this view and input a new schema name "m1" and click the "update view" button , a popup message will appear as:  Schema name "m1" already exists"
2) edit this view and input a new schema name "M1", and click the "update view" button,  a popup message will appear as:  Schema name is case-insensitive.  Schema name "m1" already exists"
Bug:20679 - check and warn existing schema
Fixed.
Bug:20679 - fixed schema name validation logic
fixed

Hi Brian, 

I was verifying these warning messages and all are looking fine for custom (new) schema name we provide.

But if do same things with 'main' schema it give no error for first time.

Steps to reproduce - 
1. Deploy latest build for 7ea1 and create a DB.
2. Now go to Create view page of it and create a view with "New Schema" as main or Main or MAIN

Please note that it doesn't not giving any warning and silently created the view. 

If we do same steps again then it started to give warnings, so this is the issue with first time View creation only.

Kindly have a look and let me know if this is expected behavior.

Thanks
Kuldeep

I believe a schema named main is not available out of the box. First time a view is created, if there is no schema specified, main is created and used as the schema.

This is why you can specify a new schema called main first time a view is created. This is working as designed
Please verify and close this defect if you agree

As per Ganesh's comment and discussion with Megha, shipping this as having SQLGUIBug20679.java in regression.
 
Thanks
Kuldeep
